Generation of carbondioxide in the atmosphere has increased considerably over the past decades due to the increase of industrialization. This led to the increase in the global temperature which affects the eco-system. It is essential to reduce the emission of carbondioxide in the atmosphere for which different researchers are working on re-utilization of the generated carbondioxide either by converting to different products or by trapping them as carbonates. Propylene carbonate is one of the chemicals that are synthesized by using CO2 as a reactant. Propylene carbonate has many applications as an end product and acts as intermediate for synthesis of other useful chemicals. Fixation of CO2 into propylene oxide for the synthesis of propylene carbonate is still a challenging task due to the high thermodynamic stability of CO2. Propylene carbonate can be synthesized by reacting CO2 with different high energy materials using different catalyst. This review is focused on providing an idea about different types of catalyst reported for synthesis of cyclic propylene carbonate using propylene oxide and propylene glycol as the starting materials. This review also provides the mechanism for conversion of CO2 to propylene carbonate by different catalyst and at various working conditions. In recent years, concentration of carbon dioxide has increased in atmosphere from 280 ppm to 413 ppm. This causes air pollution that leads to health issues, acid rains, natural calamities and increases global warming by trapping heat and radiations from sunlight [1,2]. Lopes et al. [2] reported the variation of CO2 concentrations with increase in temperature for decades. It is observed that a stiff increase in CO2 concentration leads to increase in temperature. Different methods were proposed for the reduction of emission of carbon dioxide to atmosphere such as use of renewable sources, utilization of low carbon content fuels that emits low carbon dioxide or no carbon dioxide (use of hydrogen as fuel) and geo-engineering approaches (reforestation) [3]. Currently, researchers are focussed on carbon capture and utilization (CCU) where the objective is to capture carbon dioxide (pre-combustion, post-combustion and oxy-fuel combustion), sequestration (Oil wells, ocean, deep geological cavities) and utilization of CO2 [4,5]. Sequestration of CO2 has some disadvantages such as high operational cost, leakage, capacity, safety concerns etc. [6,7]. So, it became essential to convert carbon dioxide into useful products. Because of the disadvantages associated with sequestration, it is necessary to find an alternative route for minimizing the concentration of carbon dioxide. Carbon dioxide has some unique properties such as large availability, non-flammable and low cost [8,9]. Hence, current studies are now focused on utilizing the emitted carbon dioxide by converting it to suitable alternate products that will not only reduce its concentration in atmosphere but also decreases the dependence on non-renewable resources. However, utilization of CO2 into useful products is still challenging because of its high thermodynamic stability (ΔfG298K = −396 KJ/mol) [10]. Thermodynamic stability of CO2 can be countered in presence of co reactant with higher Gibbs free energy such as hydrogen, amines and epoxides [11–13] and by providing high energy in form of heat, electricity [14]. CO2 can also be used for development of different chemicals by using catalyst that reduces the kinetic barriers [15]. Investigation has been performed in synthesis of different products using carbon dioxide as represented in Fig. 1 . These products have wide range of applications, and it can reduce the dependence on toxic compounds and petroleum products for their synthesis using traditional methods. For instance, replacement of toxic compound phosgene during synthesis of bisphenol A based polycarbonates. An alternate method for synthesis of bisphenol A based polycarbonates was proposed by Asahi Kasei [16]. Similarly, toxic di- or polyisocyanates with polyols are used for synthesis of polyurethane. Cyclic carbonates provide an alternate route for synthesis of polyurethane after reacting with amines [17]. Different organic carbonates are synthesized using carbon dioxide as a reactant using various types of catalysts. Propylene carbonate (PC) is one of the cyclic organic carbonates which has a great interest because of its different applications such as intermediate chemical for production of polycarbonate, dimethyl carbonates. PC is also used as aprotic solvent, high-permittivity component of electrolyte in lithium batteries due to high dielectric constant [18,19] (Fig. 2 ). Many routes are reported on synthesis of propylene carbonate using various catalysts, and different precursor materials. In the recent past, several excellent works have appeared that are based on the use of hetero- and/or homogeneous catalytic systems. For instance, Fiorani et al. [20] showcased the development of organocatalytic systems mainly from N-heterocyclic carbenes (NHCs) and ionic liquids (IL) in several CO2 coupling reactions. Kamphuis et al. [14] provided an extensive review focusing on the catalytic synthesis of cyclic and polymeric carbonates and advances in their applications. Shaikh et al. [21] scrutinized a series of epoxides in terms of activity, and mechanistic features. A special attention was given on various homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysts including monometallic metal-organic complexes, non-salen monometallic complexes, non-salen bimetallic complexes coordination compounds, organocatalysts, immobilized bimetallic Al (III) salen complexes and metal nanoparticles. On the other hand, Claver et al. [22] explored the advancement of CO2 mediated bio-based carbonate synthesis using of bio-based epoxide. Recently, Yan et al. [23] emphasized the importance of CO2 activation in cyclic carbonate synthesis by surveying several reported catalytic systems. Ye et al. [24] categorically concentrated on the functionalized mesoporous SiO2 for CO2 capture and its coupling reactions. We believe, rather than a complete overview of all epoxides, focusing on a particular epoxide i.e. propylene epoxide can uncover more intense details in terms of structure activity relationships, conversion of raw materials, avoidance of solvents and/or metals, and improvement of selectivity/reactivity properties. The aim of this review is to provide an overall concept and insight into the synthesis of propylene carbonate from the direct coupling of CO2 and propylene using various homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysts that can still fill a prominent position in this vibrant field of research. Hope this review is useful for encouraging researchers for the development of new catalytic synthesis methods. 2 Synthesis of cyclic propylene carbonate Cyclic propylene carbonate can be synthesized through direct and indirect methods. The direct methods include the direct reaction of carbon dioxide with the monomers at different operating conditions to produce propylene carbonate. Whereas in the indirect method, the synthesis of propylene carbonate has been performed using reaction of propylene oxide (PO) with other chemical compounds that can be produced by using carbon dioxide. This section provides detail report of different catalyst used for synthesis of PC using direct CO2 as one of the monomers. Propylene carbonate is synthesized using high energetic epoxides (propylene oxide) in the presence of suitable catalyst. Epoxides get activated and ring opening takes place when the oxygen atom of epoxide interacts with Lewis acid that can act as an electrophile and then the nucleophilic attack is occurred. The catalyst is used for the reaction mainly contains a combination of Lewis acid sites and Lewis base sites. Lewis acid site acts as electrophilic activation site and Lewis base acts as nucleophilic site. But in case of CO2, activation of CO2 can be takes place by both electrophile and nucleophile due to presence of double bond and partial negative charge on oxygen atom [25]. The mechanism of formation of PC from PO and CO2 is shown in Fig. 3 . Different heterogonous and homogenous catalysts were studied for the synthesis of PC from PO and CO2. Different types of catalyst have different advantages and disadvantages associated with it which are reported in Table 1 . In the coming section, we will discuss on different catalysts reported for development of cyclic propylene carbonate by using propylene oxide and CO2. 2.1 Homogeneous catalyst 2.1.1 Metal catalyst There are several metal elements in the crust, therefore the process of creating the raw materials needed to create metal catalysts is ongoing. Metal catalysts including transition metals, main group metals, and Rare-Earth (RE) metals have extensively been studied for cyclic carbonate synthesis. The catalytic mechanism of metal catalysts is essentially the same. Typically, the metal centre acts as a Lewis acid, activating the epoxide and causing the formation of intermediates. Next, the nucleophilic attacks to the epoxide having lower steric hindrance, promoting and realising the epoxide ring opening, which has a significant impact on the rate and duration of the reaction. Dengler et al. [26] developed tetraamine-iron complex N, N-Bis (quinolin-2-ylmethylene)−1,2-cyclohexanediamine to synthesis PC with conversion of 100 %. The reaction mechanism described the attack of epoxide on weak Fe-Cl bond and the second molecule of catalyst helps in ring opening. Back biting takes place after insertion of CO2 that reformed the catalyst. Chen et al. [27] reported that the catalytic efficiency of Chiral Co(salen) system containing Group 13 Lewis acid metal (Al, Ga, In) depends on type of nucleophile. It was found that the addition of KOH, K2CO3 or KHCO3 improvs the enantiomeric purity of PC. However, rather than alkaline salts, quaternary ammonium halides or ionic liquids as co-catalysts significantly enhance the catalytic activity. Similarly, Lu et al. [28] used chiral Salen Co(III)/quaternary ammonium halide for synthesis of PC. The anion of quaternary ammonium halide had a great effect on determine the enantiomeric purity and reaction time. Chang et al. [29] developed quaternary ammonium salt Salen Co (III)(Cl3CCO2)/phenyl trimethyl ammonium tribromide catalyst for PC synthesis with a yield of 90.2 %. The presence of lewis acid centre activated the epoxide. Br3 − attacked the activated epoxide to form an intermediate that allowed CO2 insertion to form cyclic PC. Yan et al. [30] used chiral polymers of BINOL-Salen-cobalt (III) salt for synthesis of PC. Out of different catalyst used, (R/S)-polymer catalyst and (S/R)-polymer catalyst showed a good enantioselectivity in the presence of tetra-n-butylammonium fluoride as co-catalyst. The prepared catalyst retained its property for 10 cycles. Zhang et al. [31] developed a catalytic system containing an electrophilic centre and a sterically hindered nucleophilic centre in one molecule. Pyrrolidine Salen Cr(III)X complexes with anchored sterically hindered 1,5,7-triazabicyclo[4.4.0] dec‑5-ene. The central metal ion acted as electrophilic centre and TBD as nucleophilic centre. The catalytic activity exhibited a yield of 97.4 % and selectivity of 100 %. The coordination mode has a strong correlation with the activity of aluminium complex catalyst, demonstrating its significant potential. Lu et al. [32] tested a series of bifunctional catalyst consists of tetradentate Schiff-base aluminium complexes and polyether-KY complex where the former acted as electrophile and the later acted as nucleophile. Out of different sets of catalyst systems, Salen AlEt/18-crown-6-KI was effective for PC synthesis with a yield of >99 %. The mechanism describes the opening of ring due to synergetic effect of bifunctional catalyst, resulted from nucleophilicity of free I − form 18-crown-6-KI and electrophilic interaction of Salen Al(III). Activation of CO2 takes place by nucleophilic attack of the alcoholate [OCH(R)CH2I− K +−18-crown-6]. Synergetic effect leads to formation of linear carbonate that again gets transformed to cyclic carbonate via intermolecular cyclic elimination. Darensbourg et al. [33] prepared a novel aluminium complex by reaction between AlCl3 and potassium tris(3-phenylpyrazolyl)hydroborate. The prepared catalyst was able to synthesize PC due to the presence of AlCl4 −anion. In another study, Dongsheng et al. [34] used water soluble bifunctional metalloporphyrins for synthesis of PC. Different metal lewis acidic centre were tested out of which 5,10,15,20-Tetra-(p-N,N,N-trimethylphenyl ammonium iodide) porphyrinium cobalt(III) acetate showed a yield and selectivity of 95.4 % and >99 %, respectively was used for 5 times without loss in activity. The bi-functional property of Zn2+ makes Zn-complex suitable for this reaction. Yuan et al. [35] developed dual-ligand complex that was used for cycloaddition of PO and CO2. The catalyst was prepared by reaction between ZnBr2, N-methylimidazole and tetra ethyl ammonium bromide. The structure of Zn atom surrounded by three bromine atom, nitrogen atom and a free cation atom helped in conversion of PO to PC with a yield of 85 %. Yang et al. [36] used a system of µ-oxo-tetranuclear zinc cluster (Zn4(OCOCF3)6O) and tetrabutylammonium iodide as co-catalyst for development of PC. The study found that the electrophilicity of Zn (II) ion, number of trifluoromethyl groups, nucleophilicity and leaving ability of anions of alkylammonium salts were main factors for the activity of catalyst. The yield and conversion achieved approx. 99 % each. The proposed mechanism is the ring opening of epoxide by iodide to form zinc alkoxide. The CO2 activated by second zinc metal reacted with zinc alkoxide to form zinc carbonate intermediates for formation of PC. Ono et al. [37] used microwave irradiation based solvent free method for synthesis of PC using ionic liquid-zinc salt system catalyst. Different combination of zinc salt, tetraalkylammonium halide and ionic liquids were tested, and it was found that combination of zinc phenosulfonate octahydrate and Bu4NBr was very effective with yield of 97 %. Yin et al. [38] used bismuth compounds with a sulfur-bridged bis(phenolate) ligand. Two bismuth ligands, bismuth methoxide and bismuth iodide were prepared by reaction of 2,2′-thiobis(6‑tert‑butyl‑4-methylphenol) (H2L) with Bi (OMe)3 and BiI3 with disodium salt of H2I, respectively. The prepared catalyst along with iodide salt (NaI or LiI) as co-catalyst, developed PC with conversion and yield both > 90 %. The high performance of these catalytic systems can be ascribed to the hypervalent structure, where the intermolecular coordination of the sulfur atom with the bismuth atom is very flexible and the adjustable Lewis acidity of the bismuth atom is expected to ultimately facilitate the exchange of products and reactants. Bu et al. [39] synthesized trans dichloro tetra pyridine ruthenium (II) as catalyst along with hexadecyl trimethyl ammonium bromide for cycloaddition reaction between PO and CO2 to produce PC. The ligand exchange takes place between PO and Ru-Cl due to long bond distance between Ru-Cl to form a complex. CTAB decomposes to amines and form trimethylamine that reacts with CO2 to form carbamate salts. These salts help for insertion of CO2 in epoxide to form PC. The prepared catalyst retained its activity for 4 cycles and had a yield of 98.6 % and selectivity nearly 100 %. Rare earth-based complex catalysts are not much explored. First time, Xin et el. [40] Stabilized the La-based complex (Y, Sm, Nd, and La) by polydentate N-methylethylenediamine-bridged tris(phenolato) ligands and tested for CO2-PO cycloaddition reaction ( Fig. 4 ). The synthesized catalyst displays 99% PC yield at room temperature and 0.1 Mpa. Yasuda et al. [41] used solid catalyst Lanthanide oxychloride for synthesis of PC from PO and supercritical CO2. Out of different lanthanide elements SmOCl exhibited a good yield of 57.5 % and selectivity of 97.4 % without the use of any solvent. The catalytic property was further improved by addition of polar organic solvents N, N-Dimethylformamide where the yield and selectivity increased to 99 % each. Different type of homogeneous metal catalysts for PC synthesis from CO2 and PO at different conditions is reported in Table 2 . 2.1.2 Ionic liquids (ILs) ILs are desirable nonmetal catalysts for a variety of processes because of their unique characteristics. Multiple active components are obtained by task tuning ILs to serve as efficient catalytic sites for distinct processes. The inherent anions like halogen can be the perfect nucleophile part of catalyst, which can easily activate acidic molecule like CO2. In addition, the homogeneous catalytic nature of ILs interacts with the reactant at room temperature even under mild reaction conditions, providing a good product yield. Therefore, ILs can be used for cycloaddition of CO2 with PO to produce PC. ILs bearing hydroxyl carboxyl, amino functional groups are advantageous in cycloaddition reaction. Qu et al. [42] demonstrated AAILs ([HTMG] [AA] [X], AA= (Histidine [His]2−, Lysine [Lys]−), X = Cl, Br, or I) catalyst made of superbase 1,1,3,3-tetramethylguanidine [HTMG]+, which is capable of catalyzing CO2-epoxide cycloaddition reactions effectively at ambient temperature. More specifically, 99 % of the yield of propylene carbonate was obtained by the interaction of CO2 and propylene oxide at ambient temperature and atmospheric pressure for 20 h. Yue et al. [43] reported the synthesis of dual amino functional imidazole ILs under the conditions of solvent-free helpless catalyst as CO2 and epoxide catalyst for the synthesis of cyclic carbonate reaction in response to previous reports of amino acid ILs being difficult to reuse under the ideal reaction conditions. Excitingly, the 98% yield of PC obtained when CO2 and PO were charged under 105 °C and 0.5 MPa for 13 h. Using the proper molar ratios, organic amines or alcohols (such as urea or ethylene glycol) can be combined with metal halides to create eutectic ILs. For example, urea and zinc chloride can be mixed in a 3:1 molar ratio, heated to about 100 °C, and stirred in air to create a transparent, homogeneous liquid [44]. This ILs' benefits include minimal synthesis costs, environmental friendliness, ease of use, and superior performance. In 2016, Liu et al. [45] disclosed, the [urea-Zn]I2 based eutectic based ILs, which can catalyse the reaction of CO2 with propylene oxide through a cationic structure and halogen anion. The PC yield was close to 95 % in the absence of solvents or cocatalysts. Kawanami et al. [46] synthesized PC with 100 % yield and 100 % selectivity under supercritical condition of CO2 in presence of 1-octyl-3-methylimidazolium tetrafluoroborate. Different ionic liquid systems were examined, and it was found that with increase in the alkyl chain, the yield increases due to increase in solubility of CO2. Peng et al. [47] used ionic liquids of 1-n‑butyl‑3-methylimidazolium and n‑butyl pyridinium salts of which 1-n‑butyl‑3-methylimidazolium tetrafluoroborate was found to be effective with almost 100 % selectivity and yield of 90.7 %. Similarly, Vieira et al. [48] used surface active ionic liquids composed of cations (imidazolium and tetrabutylammonium), and long alkyl chain anions of (C12 chain) derived from the surfactants: sodium lauryl sulfate ([C12SO4 −]), sodium lauryl ether sulfate ([C12ESO4 −]), sodium lauryl benzene sulfonate ([C12BSO3 −]) and sodium lauryl sarcosinate ([C12SAR−]). Out of different sets of ionic liquids, the activity of [TBA][C12SO4] was more effective with conversion of 79.2 % and selectivity of 87.7 % in presence of Lewis acid ZnBr2. Tetrabutylammonium was more effective due to its high molecular volume that increased the cation/anion distance which consequently reduces the electrostatic interaction and thus making it a more nucleophilic anion. Li et al. [49] used series of functionalized phosphonium-based ionic liquids for the synthesis of PC. It was found that carboxyl functionalized phosphonium-based ionic liquids [Ph3PC2H4COOH]Br showed a yield of 97.3 % and selectivity of 99.8 %. The carboxylic functional group helped in ring opening and nucleophilic attack by halide anion. Kim et al. [50] used ionic liquids in presence of zinc halides to synthesis PC. Different sets of imidazolium zinc tetrahalides, (1-R-3-methylimidazolium)2ZnX2Y2 were used as catalyst and it was found that the activity of the catalyst depended on the nature of halide group attached to zinc, with the order of [ZnBr4]2− > [ZnBr2Cl2]2− >> [ZnCl4]2−. The presence of Zn at centre of [ZnX2Y2]2− acted as Lewis acid and halide acted as Lewis base for ring opening. Out of different catalyst, (1-ethyl-3-methylimidazolium)2ZnBr2Cl2 showed an excellent catalytic activity for 4 consecutive cycles. Cheng et al. [51] used ZnBr2 – based chlorine chloride as catalyst with yield, selectivity of 100 %, 99 % and repeatability of 5 cycles. Activation of ring takes place by formation of hydrogen bonding and the presence of chlorine ion helped in opening of epoxy ring. Bromine ion opens the epoxy ring and –OH of choline chloride created the intermediate where the CO2 reacted to form cyclic carbonate. The synergetic effect between ZnBr2 and choline chloride promoted the reaction. Yang et al. [52] used multifunctional monocomponent zinc halide based ionic liquids (amidinothiourea-ZnI2 (ATUI) and N-phenylthiourea-ZnI2 (NTUI)) for synthesis of PC. Out of both ATUI showed a superior yield due to the synergistic effect. It was observed that ATU had more hydrogen bond donor than NTU and catalytic activity was significantly influenced by nucelophilic property of halide in order of I–>Br–>Cl–. The prepared catalyst had a yield of 97 % and selectivity of 99 %. Metal ionic liquid (MIL) synthesized by Chen et al. [53] was tested for PC synthesis under ambient conditions. The purpose of selecting MIL i.e. [Hmim]2[ZnBr4] was to create multiple sites for CO2 and epoxide adsorption as well as ring opening of epoxide (Fig. 5 ). Various type of ionic liquids (ILs) for PC synthesis from CO2 and PO at different conditions is summarized in Table 3 . 2.2 Heterogeneous catalyst 2.2.1 Metal organic frameworks (MOFs) Metal Organic Frameworks (MOFs) are porous coordinate polymers that contains a metal site bonded with organic linkers. Owing to the diverse porous structure, Lewis-acid site, low cost and biocompatibility, Zn based MOFs are the best choice as heterogenous catalysts for organic transformation at ambient conditions especially for CO2 fixation reaction [54]. MOFs were used as the catalyst for the conversion of PO to PC because of high specific surface area, controllable pore size and can be easily functionalized. Some of the MOFs shows high resistance to water, air and common solvents and good thermal stability. Kleist et al. [55] developed a series of mixed-linker based metal organic frameworks with a general formula Zn4O(BDC)x(ABDC)3–x for synthesis of PC. 2-aminobenzene-1,4-dicarboxylate (ABDC) was used as functionalized linker group in place of 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate (BDC) which act as weak basic sites in catalyst due to the presence of amino groups. The conversion of PO to PC was carried out in presence of tetraethylammonium bromide as promoter that showed a yield of 63 %. Gupta et al. [56] found exceptional thermal stable microporous {[Zn 2(3-tpom)(L)2]·2H2O}n framework is suitable for selective CO2 adsorption due to the plausible quadrupole-quadrupole interactions between CO2 with exposed oxygen functionalities. The co-presence of abundance of unsaturated sites and Lewis's acid-base interactions are accountable for high cyclic carbonate yield (Fig. 6 ). Li et al. [57] intended to design Zn-based MOF by introducing zinc (II) ions, nitrogen-rich 5-aminoterazole 3, and 5-pyrazoledicarboxylic acid for solvent-free propylene carbonate synthesis in the presence TBABr. Nitrogen-containing groups (-NH2) and Lewis acid centers (Zn2+) are responsible for CO2 adsorption and epoxide activation leading to excellent PC yields in the presence of bromide nucleophiles. Lan et al. [58] adopted a unique preparation method for the preparation of highly stable Zn2(Py)(Atz)2·DMF·2H2O framework (H2Py = 3,5-Pyridinedicarboxylic acid, Hatz= 3-Amino-1,2,4-triazole) with high surface area 764.5 m2/g and abundant micropores. The synergy between acidic (Zn2+) and basic (nitro-rich unit) sites are responsible for showing 92.1% PC yield at 60 °C and 1.5 MPa. Recently, Li et al. [59] designed microporous framework {[Zn(H2DDBB)]·2NMP}n having 1D rectangle open channels (10.0 × 7.6 Å2) for accessing the active sites situated inside the pores. Additionally, enrichment of free -COOH species, N-imidazole units, and tetra-coordinated open metal sites inside the inner wall, the synthesized MOF shows excellent yield of PC in presence of TABBr at mild conditions (Fig. 7). Tharun et al. [60] synthesized porous zeolitic imidazolate framework (ZIF-90) for conversion of propylene oxide to propylene carbonate by reaction with CO2. ZIF was a class of metal organic framework which was used as catalyst due to its good chemical and thermal stability, uniform larger pores structure and large surface area. The prepared catalyst shows conversion rate of 88 % with selectivity of 92 %. The proposed mechanism described that the activation of epoxide by the zinc atom of ZIF-50 leads to ring opening of epoxide. The oxygen atom in aldehyde part of catalyst formed a bond with carbon atom of CO2 causing formation of an eight-member ring. Further the interaction of oxygen atom of CO2 with Zn in catalyst forms a stable compound that ruptures the ring and thus PC is formed. James et al. [61] used metal-organic framework for synthesis of PC from PO and CO2. MOF were used because of thermally robust, highly porous and tunable of organic linkers and metal nodes. Different MOFs were developed by varying the metal sites by iron, chromium and Scandium. It was observed that MIL-100(Sc) showed a good yield of 57±5 % without the use of any co-catalyst. The prepared catalyst can be used for long term operation upto 24 hr without much loss in reactivity. Zhou et al. [62] developed heterogeneous catalyst consist of functionalized isoreticular metal-organic framework-3 that had a yield of 98 % of PC and selectivity >99 % with recyclability of 4 cycles. The co-ordination of epoxide oxygen atom with Zn4O or the hydrogen of –NH2 leads to polarization of CO bond and I − acted as active sites for opening of epoxy ring. The oxygen anion interacted with CO2, thereby forming alkyl carbonate anion which was further converted to cyclic carbonate. Zalomaeva et al. [63] used chromium terepthalate MIL-101 along with tetrabutylammonium bromide as co-catalyst for conversion of PO with yield of 82 % and conversion of 91 % after 24 h of operation. Here, Co-ordination takes place between epoxide and the metal center followed by ring opening due to tetrabutylammonium bromide. After the ring opening, the oxygen anion of open ring act as nucleophile that interacted with electrophilic CO2 to form carbonate ion. These ions then converted to carbonates by ring closing. Babu et al. [64] developed an amine functionalized hierarchical UMCM-1-NH2 MOF. Where Pore dimensions of 14 × 17 Å are formed by nine Zn4O clusters, six NH2-BDC units, and five BTB units, forming three-dimensional microporous cages. These microporous cages are further organized in an edge-sharing manner, resulting in a mesoporous space (dimensions 27 × 32 Å) formed by six cages. The catalyst consists of Zn4O SBUs with ligands of two-fold symmetric (NH2-BDC) and three-fold symmetric (BTB). The developed catalyst showed a conversion of 90 % and selectivity of >99 % for synthesis of PC in the presence of tetra-n-butylammonium bromide. Notably, mesopores facilitate simple guest transport and molecular accessibility, whereas micropores primarily aid in controlling catalytic contacts at active centers. As a result, mesopores outperform pure microporous or pure mesoporous MOFs in this regard. Abdelsayed et al. [65] reported Pt nanoparticles supported Mg-MOF-74 catalyst for synthesis of PC by cyclic addition of CO2 with PO. The yield and selectivity of catalyst was about 44 % and 77.2 %, respectively in the presence of dimethylformamide and dichloromethane. Babu et al. [66] reported a multilinked non-interpenetrated MOF, UMCM-15 using microwave synthesis method. The developed catalyst showed an excellent conversion, yield and selectivity of 93 %, 93 % and >99 %, respectively in the presence of TBAB. The Zn atom present at the centre of the catalyst forms a bond with oxygen of epoxide. The ring opening takes place due to the presence of bromine in TBAB. CO2 is then polarized by the action of oxygen anion present in open ring and thus forms an intermediate which further forms cyclic carbonate by eliminating the bromine ion. Ren et al. [67] used Ni (salphen) as metalloligand in MOF for synthesis of PC. The catalyst along with tetrabutylammonium bromide had a yield of 85 %. Ji et al. [68] developed Co (II) MOF with rich Lewis acid site for conversion of PO to PC with yield upto 98 % in the presence of TBAB. It was observed that by developing the catalyst through nano crystallization strategy, using surfactants, there was an enhancement in the catalytic property. Abundance of silanols favors activation of epoxides. CO2 adsorption capacity and catalytic activity of mesoporous SiO2 in cycloaddition reactions have been improved by introducing metals or functionalization with nonmetals. Researchers are introducing metal active components into mesoporous SiO2 to increase the activity of pure SiO2 due to the widespread use of metal-based catalysts and their effective catalytic activity. Wang et al. [69] synthesized MTW-type magnesium silicalite (Mg-Si-ZSM-12) with a mesoporous structure using an acid co-hydrolysis method. At room temperature, this material exhibits good catalytic activity with the help of a co-catalyst called tetrabutylammonium bromide (TBAB). Kim and Na [70] further investigated the cooperative action of nucleophiles, acid sites and Si-OH where synergistic effects give a clear improvement compared to catalysts with single catalytic functions (Fig. 8). Ammonium bromide groups and acid sites adjacent to the zeolite surface induced a low activation energy of 37.3 KJ/mol resulting in enhanced catalytic performance of metal doped SiO2. Saptal et al. [71] illustrated acid-base synergistic effect through synthesis of Zr doped and amine supported MCM-41 catalyst where 97 % propylene carbonate (PC) yield was found in presence of co-catalyst TBAI at 80 °C, 2 MPa. Here mainly, the synergistic effect between free -NH2 group and Zr sites is responsible for CO2 and epoxide activation and subsequently achieving significant PC yield(Fig. 9). Xie et al. [72] used silica supported hexa alkyl guanidinium chloride as catalyst for preparing PC in order to avoid using quaternary ammonium salts. Similarly, Wang et al. [73] used silica supported quaternary ammonium halides for synthesis of PC. From different sets of experiments, it was found that silica supported tetra-n-butylammonium bromide showed a conversion of 97 %, yields of 96 %, and retained its activity for minimum of 4 cycles. The study revealed that the anionic part had a high influence in cycloaddition of CO2 as compared to the cationic part. Polydiallyldimethylammonium chloride (PDDA) template is beneficial for generating basic sites in Ti-silicate catalyst demonstrated by Liu et al. [74]. Where the framework Ti species and quaternary ammonium salts within the catalyst act to efficiently catalyse PO to PC. Adam et al. [75] developed a solid base catalyst, tetramethylguanidine-silica nanoparticles for synthesis of PC with selectivity of 98 % and conversion of 92 %. The silica used was prepared from rice husk ash. Formation the catalyst and EFTEM image of developed catalyst is shown in Fig. 10 . The prepared catalyst retains its activity for 4 cycles. CO2 absorbed on the Lewis base site (N=) to form carbonate which attack the less sterically hindered carbon atom in epoxide which opens the ring for anion to attack the carbonyl carbon. Jagtap et al. [76] used silica supported polyvinyl pyridine for conversion of PO to PC with a yield of 91 % with 4 cycles of repetitive property. Ramin et al. [77] synthesized heterogeneous catalyst of different chromium-salen complexes immobilised on silica. The prepared sample showed a selectivity of 98 %. It was found that the catalytic activity depended on the structure of salen ligand. Active complexes formed co-valent bonds or coordinative bonds with silica, out of which the co-valent bonded catalysts exhibited a stability for the reaction conditions. Shiels and Jones [78] used 4-(N, N-Dimethylamino)pyridine as both homogenous and heterogeneous catalyst at dry condition for synthesis of PC. The yield was 85 % for DMAP and 81 % for SBA-15 immobilized DMAP. The mechanism of cycloaddition proposed was the loan pair of electrons on the pyridyl nitrogen from a single DMP molecule help in ring opening and insertion of CO2. Sadeghzadeh et al. [79] synthesized heteropolyacid based ionic liquid supported on fibrous nano-silica for conversion of epoxides to cyclic carbonates. The prepared catalyst was used for different epoxides. It was found that conversion of propylene oxide to propylene carbonate took place at moderate temperature and pressure with yield and conversion achieved was 98 % with repeatability for 10 cycles. Song et al. [80] used silica gel supported polydiallyldimethylammonium bromide and zinc bromide for cycloaddition of CO2. It was found that the developed catalyst showed a good conversion and selectivity in synthesis of PC with 98.9 % and 97.8 %, respectively. Kim et al. [81] produced zinc containing ionic liquids on silica to make it a heterogeneous catalyst for cycloaddition of CO2. The catalyst was prepared by addition of zinc halides with ionic liquids and silica gel that produced PC. Out of different series of experiments, 1-butylpyridinium bromide-ZnCl2/silica supported exhibited a yield of 98 % and selectivity of 100 %. The lewis acidic zinc forms a bond with oxygen of epoxide. The nucelophilic attack by the halide ion present in catalyst helps in ring opening and the intermediate formed reacts with CO2 to form PC. The presence of halide anions was the factor for promoting the coupling reaction due to synergistic effect. Sankar et al. [82] developed SiO2 supported Imidazole for conversion of epoxides to respective carbonates. The linkage of imidazole with silica matrix was done through propyl linkage. The lone pair of electrons in nitrogen present in imidazole helped in ring opening and also activate the CO2 simultaneously. The intermediate that is formed then arrange itself to form a cyclic carbonate. Zhang et al. [83] developed amine functionalized silica catalyst for cycloaddition of CO2 with PO to produce PC. Out of different catalyst, TBD showed a good selectivity and conversion of 99.8 % and 99.5 %, respectively. It was also observed that the catalytic activity depended on the basicity of the catalyst. The proposed mechanism stated that the activation of epoxide took place by hydrogen bonding by the surface silanols. This led to the opening of epoxide ring and insertion of CO2 took place due to synergistic effect to form linear carbonate, which then transferred to cyclic carbonate due to intermolecular substitution. Gharnati et al. [84] studied the effect on activity of catalyst based on the amount of CO2. The catalyst used for the reaction was immobilized 1-hydroxyethyl-9-propyl-cyclic guanidinium bromide on SBA-15. The phase behaviour during the reaction and the number and composition in multicomposition system was predicted by Cublic-Plus-Association equation. It was found that with increased in the amount of CO2 catalytic activity increased. The yield was found to be 22 % and conversion >90 %. Ramin et al. [85] developed zinc based mixed oxide catalyst (ZnO-SiO2) using sol-gel and flame spray pyrolysis. It was found that catalyst prepared by flame spray pyrolysis showed more active than sol-gel derived catalyst due to lower number of free hydroxyl ion for which there is decrease in active sites. The prepared catalyst had a selectivity >99 % and conversion of 100 %. Implementation, low cost, and easy accessibility. Saptal et al. [86] tested amine-functionalized graphene oxide catalyst for propylene carbonate synthesis reaction in presence of co-catalyst TBAI. The purpose of amine functionalization was to improve CO2 adsorption while different hydroxyl groups of graphene oxide meet the requirements of acidic sites for achieving improved PC yield (Fig. 11). Recently, Ghosh et al. [87] extended this idea by introducing melamine and p-toluene sulfonic acid precursors in water for the synthesis of metal free nitrogen and sulfur co-doped hollow sphere carbon catalyst (Fig. 12). Experimental study combined with DFT study suggests that pyridinic N species and terminal –SO2H are the preferred sites for the activation of CO2 and epoxide. Sun et al. [88] showed C60 fullerenol could be used as a highly active, selective and stable catalyst for PC synthesis. The reaction proceeds via solid/liquid interfacial hydrogen-bond assisted mechanism where surface hydroxyl group of C60 fullerenol acts as a weak acid, activating the epoxide through a hydrogen bond followed by nucleophilic attack by I − anion on the less sterically hindered carbon in the epoxide. To avoid using co-catalyst, Gorji et al. [89] prepared 3-bromopropanoic acid (BPA) functionalized N-doped graphene quantum dots (N-GQDs) where catalysis is initiated by CO2 activation by activation of nitrogen species and subsequent formation of carbamate intermediates. Al-Garni et al. [90] used heteropolyoxometalates (Fe1.5PMo12O40 (FePMo) Keggin heteropolyanions) for synthesis of PC in presence of tetraethyl ammonium bromide as co-catalyst. Heteropolyoxometalates catalyst was used due to its non-deactivation property in presence of water. The catalyst was supported on carbon nanotube (CNT) for better performance, because CNT has an ability to capture large amount of carbon dioxide and lowered the required high dissolved pressure of CO2 for the reaction. The prepared catalyst achieved a PO conversion of 57.7 % and PC selectivity of 99 %. Xu et al. [91] used incorporated functionalized imidazolium based ionic liquids on the surface of graphene oxide (GO) to develop catalyst for synthesis of PC from PO. The surface modification took place due to the reaction between alcoholic hydroxyl group and alkoxyl group of graphene oxide and ionic liquid, respectively. Different halides were used as ionic liquids out of which 1-(trimethoxysilyl) propyl-3–20 methylimidazolium iodide grafted GO showed a superior property with yield of 96 %, conversion of 96.4 % and selectivity of >99.5 %. The prepared sample showed 4-cycles of repeatability without loss of its property. Lan et al. [92] prepared a series of multi-functional GO materials containing silanol groups, multicationic quaternary ammonium salts and tertiary amines were synthesized in a one-pot method using hexamethylenetetramine as a precursor. They showed that GO with multi-cationic quaternary ammonium salt catalyst effectively catalyzes the cycloaddition of CO2 to PO under conditions of 90 °C and 2 MPa due to the multi-synergetic effect arising from silanol, halide anion and tertiary amine. Adeleye et al. [93] also reported graphene-inorganic heterogeneous nanocomposite catalyst of Ceria and lanthanum zirconia graphene oxide (Ce-La-Zr-GO). The catalyst was prepared by mixing aqueous solution of cerium, lanthanum and zirconium nitrate and GO under alkaline condition. The presence of metal ions acted as Lewis acid and oxygen present acted as Lewis base. Carboxylate anion formed due to CO2 adsorption on basic site whereas the PO was adsorbed on acidic site of the catalyst. The carboxylate anion helped in ring opening of epoxide and forming oxy-anion species by reacting with carbon atom of PO. Finally, dissociation of metal oxide of catalyst from oxyanions leads to ring closure and formation of PC. Prepared catalyst had a conversion of 86 %, yield of 82 % and selectivity of 94 %. Su et al. [94] applied various calcination temperature for the synthesis graphitic carbon nitride (g-C3N4) from urea. At lower temperatures, less polymerization, lower crystallinity with larger macropores was observed resulting in increased open edge defects leading to improved PC yield. XPS analysis gave clear insight into edge defects that correspond to incomplete planar structures containing partially coordinated NH2 and NH groups. Later this, Xu and co-workers [95] immobilized zinc halides (ZnX2) through suspension on pre-prepared g-C3N4 support. The anchoring of zinc halide by interaction between zinc and nitrogen not only reduces the possibility of zinc halide leaching during the reaction but also finds a solution not to use co-catalyst for epoxide ring opening. Furthermore, the cooperative action of zinc halides and nitrogen-rich g-C3N4 shows 52% PC yield in the CO2-PO cycloaddition reaction where Zn2+ acts as a Lewis acid site and g-C3N4 supports CO2 adsorption and activation. Hsan et al. [96] developed chitosan grafted multi-wall carbon nanotubes for adsorption and utilization of CO2 (Fig. 13). The prepared catalyst was able to adsorb 1.92cc/g. The developed catalyst along with tetra-n-hexylammonium bromide (THAB) showed a yield of 93 %. Polarization of CO bonds of epoxide took place due to presence of catalyst and co-catalyst. Presence of free bromine atom helped in ring opening of epoxide due to attack on less hindered carbon. The supported part of catalyst helped in bringing the CO2 and epoxide closer by weak van der Waal interaction and hydrogen bonding among hydrogen of amide and hydroxyl group of the catalyst with the oxygen atom of carbon dioxide and epoxide. Further cycloaddition took place to form the carbonate. Monteiro et al. [97] developed a catalyst by supporting ionic liquid 1-methyl-3-(3-trimethoxysilylpropyl) imidazolium chloride on pristine sodium titanate nanotubes and nanowires. The developed catalyst achieved a 100 % conversion for TNT and TNW supported catalyst and yield of 48 % and 60 %, respectively in the presence of co-catalyst ZnBr2 for 3 cycles without much loss in activity. The mechanism of formation of PC was reported where nucleophilic attack by IL anions takes place to less hindered carbon atom of epoxide ring and the presence of ZnBr2 helps in ring opening. The CO2 activation takes place due to Cl present in IL or the Ti atom in TNT or TNW. Mujmule et al. [98] synthesized glucose carbonaceous material, oxalic-glucose carbonaceous material and Urea-glucose carbonaceous material using hydrothermal method. The prepared catalyst along with KI as co-catalyst developed cyclic propylene carbonate by cycloaddition of CO2 with PO. Out of different systems urea-glucose carbonaceous material/ KI exhibited an excellent conversion and selectivity of 99.94 % and ≥99 %, respectively. The presence of nitrogen (-NH) and hydroxyl (-OH) group in catalyst helped in cycloaddition of carbon dioxide with PO. The basic nitrogen reacts with CO2 forms the carbamate salt, whereas –OH group helped in activation of epoxide. The presence of I − lead to ring opening of epoxide by nucleophilic attack. The oxygen anion reacted with carbamate salt to form carbonate ion which then converted to alkyl carbonate by intermolecular ring closing. Table 6 reported various carbon-based catalysts for synthesis of PC at different working conditions. 2.2.4 Supported ionic liquids-based catalysts (SILCs) Despite many advantages, ionic liquids (ILs) have several drawbacks, including high viscosity, high separation cost, and the corrosive nature of the attached halide anions. As a result, immobilizing ILs on certain solids, such as silica, MOF, and polymerizing ILs into PILs are both effective solutions to this problem. The advantage of using supported ILs is that co-catalyst separation from the reaction mixture can be solved avoiding the use of homogeneous co-catalysts. Supported ionic liquid catalysts (SILCs) also known as heterogenized ionic liquids can be prepared by physisorption or chemisorption. In the physisorption process, hydrogen bonding and van der Waals forces are involved in forming bonds between ILs and porous solids while in the chemisorption process, a strong chemical bond formation takes place between ILs and active moieties of a support [99]. Incipient wetness impregnation is a common physisorption process where confinement of the IL to the porous support (activated carbon, silica gel and alumina) occurs during slow addition of the IL to the porous support followed by solvent evaporation. The resultant heterogeneous catalyst retains same behavior of homogeneous ILs but leaching of ILs from support mainly under liquid phase conditions is the matter concern [100]. Sol-gel process is another type of physisorption process that is often employed to synthesize a support material containing cationic moieties. Here, organotrialkyloxysilane (having various IL cationic groups such as imidazolium groups) is treated with a template (silicon source such as tetraethylorthosilicate (TEOS)) followed by TEOS extraction [99,101]. Finally, the addition of metal halides leads to the formation of ionic complexes. This process is useful for integrating long alkyl chain ILs as well as obtaining high ILs loading but is not as efficient for integrating short alkyl chain ILs ([EMIm]BF4) as they are washed away under refluxing conditions [102]. Covalent immobilization process: through this approach, leaching problem can be resolved as a strong bond is formed between ILs and active moieties/silanol groups of supports. In this method, an organic group containing an imidazole site is grafted onto a solid surface, then modified with a metal halide to form an IL-structure. The mesoporous silica, carbon nanotube and polymers are the preferred supports for this approach. Xiao et al. [103] first proposed the use of supported ILs in the fixation of CO2 in 2006. They successfully catalysed the conversion of CO2 to cyclic carbonate using immobilized ILs-zinc chloride polyphase catalysts in the absence of cosolvent. The catalyst was stable and reusable twice with maximum PC yield of 98% at 110 °C and 1.5 MPa. Martinez et al. [104] adopted direct impregnation and covalent immobilization method for the preparation various ILs supported mesoporous SiO2 catalyst for continuous synthesis of PC. Although the catalyst prepared by direct impregnation is superior in terms of PC yield but rapidly deactivates with reaction time as ILs is washed away during reaction. Thus, covalent immobilization method becomes the center of interest. In this context, Muniandy and co-worker [105] demonstrated that the covalent immobilization method significantly improves the stability of Imi-MCM-41 catalysts by introducing several alkyl halides. The reaction proceeds by the combine effect of tertiary or quaternary N and halide through CO2 activation and ring-opening. Zhang et al. [106] immobilized triethanolamine-based ILs on SBA-15. It is predicted that the immobilization takes place via loss of Si-OH which is compensated by the -OH group of triethanolamine through dehydration condensation. DFT calculations reveal that hydrogen bond formation results in CO elongation in epoxides, which is beneficial for CO cleavage upon nucleophile attack. Wang et al. [107] also used silica supported ionic liquid for synthesis of PC with 99 % purity. The ionic liquid used for the study was 1‑butyl‑3-methylimidazolium tetrafluoroborate where the yield was found to be 96 % and selectivity of >99 % with recyclability for 4 cycles. Shi et al. [108] developed multiple active site ionic liquid SBA-15 supported catalyst for synthesis of PC from PO and CO2. Out of different [IMCA]2Br2@SBA-15 showed an excellent yield and selectivity of 97.4 % and 100 %, respectively. The carboxyl group weakened the interaction of CO bond by producing the hydrogen bonding. Presence of halide ions helped in epoxide ring opening and then insertion of CO2 took place at the opened epoxide ring to form the carbonate ion which then forms the cyclic carbonate by electrophilic addition. Liu et al. [109] coupled zwitterionic imidazole-urea derivative framework to mesoporous SiO2, where increasing the amount of ILs proved to be effective in improving the reactivity through increasing the overall nucleophilicity. Jin et al. [110] showed that the addition of bis(trifluoromethylsulfonyl) imide anion‐based dual imidazolium ILs during preparation of periodic mesoporous organosilica is another way to obtain higher loading of ILs. The synergistic effect from the dual anionic sites of the imidazolium IL and the hydroxyl group of the organosilica is responsible for the higher PC yield. A cross-linked divinylbenzene polymer made of hydroxyl ionic liquid was designed by Dai et al. [111]. The bromide ions and the hydroxyl groups work jointly to attain 97.6% PC yield at 140 °C and 2 Mpa. Further, Wu et al. [112] showed the chemical bonding of Imidazolium ionic liquid (1-(3-sulfopropyl)−3-methylimidazolium bromide) to UiO-66-NH2 is beneficial for improving the structural stability resulting in easy recovery with efficient catalytic performance in PC synthesis. Wang et al. [113] developed an acid-base bi-functional catalyst by immobilizing ionic liquid on MIL-101-NH2. Catalyst was synthesized by adding 1-carboxyethyl-3-methylimidazolium chloride (IL) to MIL-101-NO2 followed by converting it to MIL-101-NH2 by reacting with SnCl2·2H2O. The developed catalyst can produce PC with a yield of 91 %. The mechanism for formation of PC took place as polarization of CO bond through bond formation between hydrogen atom in –COOH and oxygen atom of epoxides that led to the ring opening. The presence of amine group in catalyst forms a strong chemisorption site for CO2. Thus, the interaction took place between absorbed CO2 and open ring epoxide to form alkylcarbonate anion that further transformed to cyclic carbonate. Guo et al. [114] synthesized a composite ILs by introducing polyether imidazole ionic liquids and ZnBr2 (co-catalyst) and then immobilized on ZSM-5. Notably, the synthesized catalyst achieved excellent selectivity of 97.4 % and conversion of 98.3 % in short time and showed outstanding heterogenicity up to 8 consecutive cycles. Recently, Du et al. [115] synthesized mesoporous dicationic imidazolium derived poly(ionic liquid)s in the propylene carbonate synthesis and subsequently predicted reaction mechanism through DFT calculations. It was found that the efficient catalytic activity of that copolymer is mainly related to the donation of the C-2 active proton of imidazole. Various type of supported ILs catalysts for PC synthesis at different conditions is mentioned in Table 7 . 2.2.5 Resins-based catalyst Ion-exchange resins have received a lot of interest as one type of polystyryl-supported catalyst that contains an ammonium salt or amino group because of its eco-friendly properties and unique catalytic behaviour [116]. Particularly polystyryl-supported catalyst bearing -OH, -COOH and -NH2 groups as a hydrogen bond doner found to be effective for the activation of epoxide. Du et al. [117] synthesized highly purified (>99.3 %), PC with yield (>97 %) and selectivity (>99 %) using insoluble ion exchange resins as catalyst. A series of catalyst were used for synthesis of PC at supercritical condition of CO2 which also acted as a solvent. Resins with quaternary ammonium or amino group was found to be most effective catalyst as compared to the acidic cation exchange resins, the chelate ion exchanger, and a polar macroporous adsorption resin, as these were found to be inactive for production of PC. Presence of ammonium ion and halide ion in quaternary ammonium acted for activation of epoxide and CO2. The dependence of functional group was also studied where activity was found to be tertiary amine > secondary amine > primary amine based on the order of the basic strength. Similarly, the effect of halide was also tested where order of activity depends on the nucleophilicity of the anion and was found to be TBAI < TBABr < TBACl. The prepared catalyst was found to be effective for more than cycles. Alassmy et al. [118] reported that two different ion-exchanged amberlite resin beads containing two different ammonium functional groups (trimethylammonium and dimethyl ethanol ammonium cations) showed higher PC yields in the presence of water (Fig. 14). The remarkable activity of Amb-OH-I-910 is mainly due to the presence of −OH species which enhance the hydrogen-bonding interaction in presence of water. Zhang et al. [119] grafted 1-(2-bromoethyl)−3-(2-nitrilethyl) imidazolium bromide in polystyrene resin to develop a multi-layered supported ionic liquid. These supported ionic liquids were then reacted with HCl to obtain the carboxylic group in the ionic structure. Different ionic liquids used, PS-ImEImECOOHI2 showed a superior performance with selectivity and yield of 99 % and 94.4 %, respectively. The synergistic interaction of anions and cations in multi-layered supported ionic liquids helped to produce cyclic carbonates with high yield. Mechanistically, the hydrogen atom in carboxylic acid group activated the epoxide ring and the presence of I − anion which acted as Lewis base helped in ring opening. CO2 gets activated by the nitrogen of imidazolium through nucleophilic attack to form alkyl carbonate ion. The PC is then formed by intermolecular ring closing. From an industrial point of view, continuous mode operation is much better than batch process. In this regard, Zhang et al. [120] selected continuous mode operation by preparing a polymer supported onium salt catalyst, composed of methyl imidazole onium salt, zinc bromide and phenol formaldehyde resin. They obtained that the catalyst performs efficiently for 72 h with a PC yield of 96 %. It was seemed that certain amount of metal halide (Lewis acid) and phenol formaldehyde resin can boost up performance of alkyl imidazole onium salt. Acceleration of reaction by Lewis acid follows the order of ZnI2 ≈ ZnBr2>ZnCl2 ≈FeBr3 ≈AlBr3 > FeCl3 ≈ AlCl3. On the other hand, Cho et al. [121] adopted both batch and continuous process. They developed immobilized ion exchange resin by using different zinc salts and a chlorine-anion exchange resin, Amberlite IRA-900. Out of different catalysts, ZnBr2/IER showed an excellent yield of 83 % & at 100 °C and 2.7 Mpa in batch process. However, the long-lasting catalytic performance (96 h and PC yield 86 %) in continuous mode implies that the catalyst is highly stable. The chemically immobilize imidazolium based ionic liquids exhibits various anions (Cl−, Br−) and diol functionalities with polystyrene resin (CMPS) through covalent bonding. The resulting catalyst shows high activity stability and reusability due to the presence of two hydroxyl groups especially vicinal hydroxyl group which has better ring opening ability than ILs containing monohydroxyl group. Also, the strong chelating ability of the hydroxyl groups through hydrogen bonding leads to the formation of a sTable 6-membered intermediate [122]. Table 8 summarized different type of resin-based catalysts for PC synthesis at different conditions. 2.2.6 Biomass-derived catalyst Biomass-derived solid catalysts are obtained from natural sources, representing environmentally friendly catalysts as they have no serious disposal problems due to their degradability [123]. In addition, its simple functionalization, tunable acidity and low modification cost make it a potential candidate for several acid catalysed reactions. Owing to the presence of abundant of functional groups such as -OH, -COOH, biomass derived catalyst can be used for epoxide activation [124]. However, either the functionalization of nucleophilic species or the use of nucleophiles with biomass-derived catalysts is necessary for the ring-opening of the epoxide. Kumar et al. [125] demonstrated chitosan (biopolymer) based meso‑tetrakis (4-sulfonatophenyl) porphyrin for both adsorption and conversion of CO2 to propylene carbonate using PO. The catalyst had an adsorption capacity of 0.9 mmol CO2/gm of catalyst. The above catalyst along with tetrabutylammonium iodide as co-catalyst exhibited a yield of 66 %. Zhao et al. [126] used chitosan modified with quaternary ammonium salt. Chitosan was used for its biocompatibility, biodegradability and non-toxic properties. Different series of modified chitosan catalyst were studied for conversion of propylene oxide out of which hydroxypropyl triethylammonium chloride functionalized chitosan showed a good activity with selectivity of >99 % and yield of 98 % for several cycles. An interesting chitosan modification was done by Tharun et al. [127] instead of making covalent bond between quaternized species (quaternary ammonium or imidazolium salts) and the chitosan backbone. They carried out quaternization of chitosan by primary amine followed by treatment with KI to synthesize the desired catalyst. Later they found that quaternization by microwave assisted route is advantageous for improving PC yield than the conventional route. Additionally, quaternized chitosan with shorter alkyl chains (CH3I) showed better nucleophilicity resulting in better performance [128]. Korosteleva et al. [129] used rhodium complex modified with organophosphorus ligands and chitosan for conversion of PO to PC. From different rhodium complexes, system of rhodium chloride, triphenylphosphine and chitosan achieved a superior catalytic property with 100 % selectivity and conversion of PO. The addition of chitosan increased the activity of rhodium triphenyl-containing systems. Sun et al. [130] synthesized chitosan functionalized 1-ethyl-3-methyl imidazolium halide (Cl, Br) where bi-functional roles i.e. the hydrogen bond-mediated ring-opening of epoxide and tertiary nitrogen-assisted CO2 activation is the main reason for the attainment of 96% PC yield. Similarly, Roshan et al. [131] synthesized imidazolium based ionic liquids supported carboxymethyl cellulose for conversion of PO to PC. Out of different imidazolium based ionic liquids, 1-Butyl-3-(3-triethoxysilylpropyl) imidazolium iodide supported on carboxymethyl cellulose showed an excellent conversion, yield and selectivity of 99 %, 98.8 % and >99 %, respectively. Experimental studies combined with DFT studies showed that a synergistic effect of carboxyl and hydroxyl species from carboxymethyl cellulose and halide ions leads to efficient cycloaddition reactions. Peng et al. [132] prepared three amino-bridged bis-β-cyclodextrin biomass-based catalysts. It was observed that bis-β-cyclodextrin along with KI as co-catalyst achieved yield and selectivity of 94 % and 99 %, respectively, while ammonium-functionalized bis-β-cyclodextrin achieved 100 % and 99 % respectively. Besse et al. [133] used a modified chitosan catalyst for synthesis of cyclic carbonate in the presence of KI. The chitosan was first modified with glycidyl trimethylammonium chloride, Allyl glycidyl ether. Then the sample was again modified with 3-mercaptopropionic acid and 4,4′-azobis (4-cyanovaleric acid to develop the catalyst that showed a yield of 89 %. Table 9 highlights various biomass derived catalysts for PC synthesis at different conditions. 2.2.7 Other catalyst To date, metal oxides have played a dominant role in catalysis industry. Several oxide catalysts were studied for PC synthesis. Commonly, monometallic oxide catalysts such as MgO and Nb2O5 do not perform well for this reaction since they had few active sites [134,135]. Zhao et al. [136] synthesized KI supported amphoteric ZnO catalyst and achieved a conversion of 95.3 % and yield of 94.3 %, respectively. The acid-base site on the surface of amphoteric ZnO increased the activity of KI and acid-base pairs of Iδ−Znδ+and Oδ−Kδ+ acted as active sites for conversion. However, the replacement of Mg by Al in the MgO matrix leads to Mg-O-Al bonds that facilitate the attainment of 88 % cyclic carbonate yields through the emergence of acid-base sites [137]. Kulal et al. [138] synthesized Mn-Ba and Sn-Ni mixed oxides via co-precipitation method. They showed the individual oxides (Mn, Ba, Ni and Sn) differs significantly in terms of acidity and basicity than to Mn-Ba and Sn-Ni mixed oxide. The high catalytic activity of Mn-Ba and Sn-Ni is attributed with total weak and medium acid-base sites (Fig. 15). Ramin et al. [85] reported that both doped and undoped zinc oxide are active in this reaction but when the zinc precursor is deposited on the preformed silica matrix, the yield of propylene carbonate can be achieved up to 99 % due to the formation of zinc oxide clusters. In another study, Yasuda et al. [139] synthesized an acid-base bifunctional cesium-phosphorus-silicon mixed oxide catalyst that was highly active (94 % yield) only at supercritical conditions at 200 °C. Lin et al. [140] showed that the functionalization of 3-aminopropyl trimethoxysilane with Zr–Mg mixed oxide improves the basic site concentration as well as eliminates the need of co-catalyst in propylene carbonate synthesis process. Trimetallic oxides including Ce−Zr−La [93] and Zn-Mg-Al [141] have also been found to be effective in the synthesis of cyclic carbonates. Rare earth oxides combined with Zr produced a yield of around 66 %, whereas bifunctional Zn-Mg-Al oxide with both acidity and basicity produced a high yield of (88.8 %). Adeleye et al. [142] used different heterogeneous catalyst for cycloaddition reaction of PO and CO2. Different catalyst was studied that included ceria and lanthanum doped zirconia, ceria doped zirconia, lanthanum doped zirconia, lanthanum oxide and zirconium oxide. Out of different catalyst ceria and lanthanum doped zirconia (Ce-La-Zr-O) along with La2O3 showed an effective catalyst with a yield of 66 %, 93 % conversion and 72 % selectivity. The used catalyst can be used for 5 cycles. Guo et al. [143] used functionalized composite catalysts for conversion of PO to PC with a yield of 61.6 %. The catalysts were made by immobilising the ionic liquids (ILX/(ZnBr2)2) with hydroxyl, carboxyl amino group on molecular sieves with the help of 3-chloropropyltriethoxysilane. Out of different samples, MCM-22-CPTES-[AeMIM][Zn2Br5] exhibited the good catalytic performance from other developed catalyst. Table 10 reported various type of catalysts for PC synthesis from CO2 and PO at different conditions. 2.3 Eutectic solvents as catalyst Deep eutectic solvents are catalysts that possess analogous properties of that of ionic liquids. The advantages of these catalysts are the low cost, biodegradable and easy preparation. Deep eutectic solvents are prepared by addition of hydrogen bond donor and hydrogen bond acceptor at a certain stoichiometric ratio [144]. Wu et al. [145] carried out cycloaddition of carbondioxide with propylene oxide in the presence of choline chloride based deep eutectic solvent (HBA) along with PEG200 (HBD) as catalyst. Different combinations and catalyst were tested as catalyst from which the above system exhibited a superior performance with selectivity of 99.6 %, yield of 94.6 % and conversion of 94.9 %. The prepared sample retained its activity for 5 cycles. The hydrogen bond activated the epoxide and absorption of CO2 took place by PEG200. The ring opening of epoxide took place by nucleophilic attack of chlorine and thus insertion of CO2 takes place at OH bond. Lu et al. [146] used l-proline/propanedioic acid system (amino acid and dicarboxylic acid-based DES) as catalyst for preparation of PC along with ZnBr2. The prepared catalyst exhibited a yield of 98 % and repeatability for 9 cycles. The mechanism of the formation of PC is shown in Fig. 16 . The formation of PC takes place using two different parallel routes where the CO2 reacted with nitrogen atom present in l-proline to form carbamate. Another parallel reaction step takes place where activation of epoxide ring takes place by forming hydrogen bonding between oxygen atom of epoxide and propanedioic acid. Presence of Br− leads to opening of epoxide ring by nucelophilic attack. The carbamate and the open epoxide rings reacted to form the cyclic carbonate. Wang et al. [147] developed 1-Butyl-3-methylimidazolium chloride (BmimCl)-based ternary deep eutectic solvent for cycloaddition of PO with CO2. Combination of catalyst, glutaric acid and boric acid achieved a conversion of 92 % and yield 98.3 % with 5 cycles of repeatability. Hydrogen bonding was formed between the oxygen atom of epoxide and hydroxyl group of glutaric acid and boric acid that activated the epoxide. The ring opening took place by nucleophilic attack of Cl− and then attack of CO2 to form alkyl carbonate species. CCl bond was attacked by developed alkyl carbonate that forms PC. 2.4 Propylene glycol and carbondioxide Propylene carbonate is also synthesized by using aliphatic diols. Different catalysts have been reported for synthesis of cyclic carbonates. But the disadvantage of this method for synthesis of PC is the formation of water as side product. The generation of water acts as poison to catalyst that leads to low yield of PC [148]. To overcome this problem, the reaction is associated with dehydrating agents to improve yield and selectivity are reported using propylene glycol along with CO2 for synthesis of propylene carbonate. Silva et al. [148] directly synthesized PC by reacting PG and super critical CO2 in presence of benzonitrile as dehydrating agent. Different anhydrous alkali carbonates and metal oxides were used as catalyst. Out of these potassium carbonate exhibited a superior property with yield, selectivity and conversion of 20 %, 45 % and 44 %, respectively. Huang et al. [149] used different organic bases (strong non-ionic nitrogen bases) as catalyst along with acetonitrile. Acetonitrile acted as dehydrating agent as well as solvent. It was observed that the yield of PC depends on the basicity. Strong base provided good result due to their spontaneous ability for hydrolysis of acetonitrile. To increase the selectivity of PC, ammonium carbonate was also used as coupling agent during the reaction. Decomposition of ammonium carbonates produced ammonia that inhibited the acetamide to further hydrolysis to acetic acid. The prepared catalyst produced PC with yield of 15.3 % and conversion of 100 %. Huang et al. [150] used series of modified zinc oxide along with acetonitrile for synthesis of PC from PG and CO2. The zinc oxide was modified by impregnating alkali carbonate and alkali halide. Out of different compositions KI/ZnO system showed a yield of 26 % and selectivity was further improved to nearly 100 % on addition of ammonium carbonate but the yield decreased. Zhao et al. [151] used different zinc salts for synthesis of PC where zinc acetate had a conversion, yield and selectivity of PC were 19.2 %, 12.3 %, and 64.1 % respectively. Du et al. [152] used dibutyltin oxide or dibutyltin dimethoxide was used in presence of N, N-dimethylformamide as co-solvent for synthesis of PC. Ketals was used as dehydrating agent to remove water which forms as by-product of the reaction. Dibutyltin oxide reacted with PG to form 2,2-dibutyl-1,3,2-dioxastannolan. Insertion of CO2 took place at Sn-O and then separation of PC due to intermolecular nucleophilic attack of alkoxy group on a carbonyl carbon atom. Tomishige et al. [153] used CeO2-ZrO2 solid solution catalyst for conversion of PG to PC with selectivity >99.9 %. It was also studied that the BET surface area depends on the calcined temperature and Ce content. Castro-Osma et al. [154] prepared a catalyst by using zinc trifluoro methane sulfonate and zinc p-toluene sulfonate. Acetonitrile was used as the dehydrating agent for the reaction. But the disadvantage of using acetonitrile as dehydrating agent is it produces number of by-products from water such as acetamide, acetic acid, and acetylated glycols. It was found that zinc trifluoro methane sulfonate showed a yield of 53 %, conversion of 75 % and selectivity of 69 % whereas in case of zinc p-toluene sulfonate, yield of 48 %, conversion of 77 % and selectivity of 62 % was achieved. Shi-yong et al. [155] used different metallic acetates for synthesis of PC. Out of different metallic catalysts, zinc acetate showed an effective catalytic activity with a yield of 24.2 % and selectivity of 38.9 %. The water which was produced as side product was absorbed by acetonitrile. Acetonitrile was used as dehydrating agent and as solvent for the reaction. Du et al. [156] used magnesium and different metal oxides for synthesis of PC. It was found that the use of Mg as catalyst increased the activity with selectivity of 100 % but the yield was low which may be due to formation of water. It was also found that the single component catalyst such as MgO, ZnO and Al2O3 had a good activity and selectivity of >99.9 %, 97.3 % and 52.2 %, respectively. Mg or MgO reacted with PG to form magnesium alkoxide. Insertion of CO2 takes place at metal-oxygen bond thereby forming cyclic magnesium carbonate. Then subsequent intermolecular nucleophilic attack takes place that releases the PC. Huang et al. [157] used alkali carbonate for synthesis of PC from PG. The catalyst was accompanied with acetonitrile (dehydrating agent as well as solvent) and ammonium carbonate was used to enhance the selectivity. It was observed that with increased in basicity, the yield increased due to hydrolysis of acetonitrile. The yield reached 10.5 % and selectivity of 100 %. Moving towards sustainable methods, anchoring or functionalization of nucleophiles is the best way to obtain effective catalytic systems free of co-catalysis. Table 11 suggests that halide functionalization is the best way to avoid direct use of co-catalysts. However, it is noteworthy that a relatively high pressure in the absence of co-catalyst is productive for achieving high cyclic carbonate yields. 3 Conclusions and prospects The reaction of CO2 with propylene oxide to form cyclic carbonates is a promising way to utilize CO2, and the formed propylene carbonate has attracted immense attention due to its use as polar solvents, chemical building blocks for pharmaceuticals and fine chemicals, biomedical applications, and electrolytic components in lithium battery. Here, we have summarized advances on various catalytic system for CO2-propylene cycloaddition reaction. These include various homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysts such as metal catalysts, ionic liquids, MOF, silica-based and carbon-based, supported ionic liquids, biomass derived catalysts, and resin-based catalysts which have great potential in propylene carbonate synthesis. The importance of catalytic systems is mainly associated with the coordination between acidity and basicity in addition to the porosity, surface area, thermal stability for heterogeneous catalysts. There, the efficiency of a catalyst is defined by means of their recyclability, selectivity, and yield of product at ambient conditions. Mechanistically, it can be stated that a catalyst should have two properties for this reaction. More specifically, a combination of basic site and an acid site (e.g., metal or proton) is required to initiate the reaction through activation of CO2 and PO. Then in the presence of a nucleophile (e.g., tetraalkylammonium halide) the activated ring undergoes ring opening to form a halo-alkoxide. Finally, halo-alkoxide reacts with activated CO2 to form PC with the regeneration of catalyst and nucleophile. Sometimes co-catalysts or nucleophiles or nucleophile-like properties are grafted or immobilized onto solid catalysts to avoid separation problems. Nevertheless, leaching of co-catalyst during reaction is a major concern. Hence, designing stable catalyst with desirable properties is highly challenging. Apart from catalyst properties, reaction conditions such as temperature, pressure, co-catalyst and its amount, catalyst amount play a decisive role in obtaining efficient catalytic performance. Performing CO2-PO cycloaddition reaction at atmospheric pressure is always preferable but most of the times high pressures (> 1atm) are applied as reaction is highly exothermic especially when the co-catalyst is grafted onto the solid catalyst instead of being used directly. In addition, higher pressure reduces reaction time while lower pressure requires prolonged reaction times to achieve the same activity. Since the reaction is exothermic, a certain range of reaction temperature (70–140 °C) has a positive effect on the production of PC because of the increased inhomogeneity of the catalyst in the reaction, PO is efficiently mobilized on the active sites of the catalyst. Which in turn more efficient collisions with PO molecules to overcome the energy barrier for ring-opening and CO2 insertion. However, excessively high temperatures are detrimental to PC selectivity. At higher temperatures, there is a decrease in CO2 dissolution, which leads to an insufficient supply of CO2 in the liquid, resulting in the appearance of some secondary products such as diols, dimers, etc. Generally, the selection of co-catalysts, if required, is another key parameter to obtain high yields of PC. For instance, TBAI turns out to be an efficient co-catalyst among TBABr, TBACl, and TBAF owing to larger size I − which has better leaving tendency than other anions. As a result, electron donation to PO becomes more favourable for the ring opening process. Relatedly, other Lewis bases, such as DMAP and DABCO, have a high affinity to coordinate with the acidic site of the catalyst rather than participating in the ring opening process, making the acid sites less available for activation of PO. Also, optimization of the amount of co-catalyst is also very important otherwise excessive use of co-catalyst causes binding of the anionic part of the co-catalyst with acidic protons which again disrupts the epoxide activation. Similarly in the presence of an excess amount of catalyst, the non-isothermal effect comes into play where the temperature varies significantly from the catalyst particle fluid temperature resulting in reduced catalyst performance. Therefore, all reaction parameters related to cyclic carbonate synthesis need to be optimized to bring out the best performance of a catalyst. Despite remarkable progress over a decade, several issues should be taken seriously. (1) Due to the strong activation ability of Lewis metal centers towards epoxides, metal-based catalysts show outstanding catalytic performance under ambient conditions but metal aggregation and leaching problems demand to explore metal-free catalysts. (2) Co-catalysts are often employed to increase reaction activity, although the most popular halide co-catalyst is prone to corrosion of the facilities and is also challenging to recycle. Immobilized ionic liquids may alleviate some problems but again their stability under high reaction pressure is a matter of debate. (3) Another important point is to large scale implementation of the synthesized catalyst where mass and heat transfer resistance mostly control the overall performance. (4) Finally, it is important to note that designing a catalyst for large-scale deployment requires scalable synthesis from elements that are abundant on Earth. Overall, more research is needed to address all the questions before industrialization can be thought about. coredata.dc:description: Generation of carbondioxide in the atmosphere has increased considerably over the past decades due to the increase of industrialization. This led to the increase in the global temperature which affects the eco-system. It is essential to reduce the emission of carbondioxide in the atmosphere for which different researchers are working on re-utilization of the generated carbondioxide either by converting to different products or by trapping them as carbonates. Propylene carbonate is one of the chemicals that are synthesized by using CO2 as a reactant. Propylene carbonate has many applications as an end product and acts as intermediate for synthesis of other useful chemicals. Fixation of CO2 into propylene oxide for the synthesis of propylene carbonate is still a challenging task due to the high thermodynamic stability of CO2. Propylene carbonate can be synthesized by reacting CO2 with different high energy materials using different catalyst. This review is focused on providing an idea about different types of catalyst reported for synthesis of cyclic propylene carbonate using propylene oxide and propylene glycol as the starting materials. This review also provides the mechanism for conversion of CO2 to propylene carbonate by different catalyst and at various working conditions.
coredata.dc:title: Review on the recent advances in catalytic conversion of carbon dioxide for synthesis of cyclic propylene carbonate
